history.content:
Hi there- 

If you want to study pure CS, you can study either EECS or L&S Computer Science. The EECS major requires one additional EE course, so if you really dislike EE, you may wish to go the LSCS route. LSCS allows you to more easily double in pure math if that is something you wish to do. 

Others on there have noted that some knowledge of hardware is important even if you plan to work in pure CS. I think this is a point worth acknowledging. 

You're correct that LSCS students are very much on par with EECS students. The data we have at the department level shows that LSCS students and EECS students have very similar if not the same opportunities after graduation.

I believe the people you are noting are speaking in regards to admissions. If you know you want to come to study CS, then its safest to apply as an EECS major and be guaranteed your major once you are accepted. There is an unfortunate risk every student entering L&S takes that they won't meet the GPA cap and be unable to get a Bachelor's Degree in CS (whereas if they had applied to EECS and been rejected they could study at another good school) without transferring away from Cal.

As a senior who is done recruiting I can tell you that employers don't care at all, students don't care either (only in 61A will you maybe hear students look down on intended CS majors), when you reach the upper division courses, many people don't even know if other people are L&S or EECS.

I was curious why many people are saying that if one wants to study pure CS they should major in EECS rather than CS. Is this true? what is the department's policy / employer's policy. Also do graduate schools like EECS better than CS? It seems weird because the 3.3 makes CS students seem to be on par with EECS students. 

FYI I don't like physics or EE but like pure math.

Any thoughts?
history.subject: EECS vs CS for pure CS
